In Sri Lanka, there was no civilian war. For nearly 30 years, the conflict was between the Sri Lankan government and the terrorist group LTTE.  It was not a war among civilians, nor was it a civil war where citizens fought each other. Instead, it was a government-led fight against terrorism, because the LTTE carried out violent attacks, assassinations, and bombings that harmed thousands of innocent civilians, both Sinhalese and Tamils.  So, it is more accurate to call it a war against terrorism, not a civilian war.

What exactly is this justice that Britain seeks? It is certainly not universal, nor impartial. The UK has never sanctioned its own war criminals, nor has it held accountable the architects of its colonial-era massacres. Winston Churchill, whose economic policies during World War II starved three million Bengalis to death in the Bengal famine of 1943, has never been posthumously condemned. The vast wealth stolen from India, estimated at $45 trillion over two centuries, has never been returned.  The survivors of the Mau Mau Uprising in Kenya, who were tortured in British-run detention camps, were only offered meagre financial settlements decades later, long after most had died. Sri Lanka doesnâ€™t even have proper records of the indigenous people who were virtually wiped out by the British. During British colonial rule in Burma, an estimated one million people died due to factors such as the Anglo-Burmese Wars, forced labour, military repression, and the devastating famine of 1942, which alone claimed between 300,000 to 500,000 lives.  Additionally, the forced relocation of indigenous peoples in Australia and the suppression of their cultures were part of Britainâ€™s colonial atrocities. The exploitation of enslaved Africans and the brutal slave trade in the Caribbean also represents a dark chapter in British history, contributing to the immense wealth of the empire at the expense of human lives. None of these crimes have led to sanctions, nor have there been meaningful legal consequences.  Britainâ€™s crimes extend beyond its colonial past into modern conflicts. During the Malayan Emergency, British forces executed civilians, burned villages, and detained thousands in camps. In Cyprus, they tortured anti-colonial detainees. The UKâ€™s 2003 invasion of Iraq caused widespread destruction, while its 2011 intervention in Libya led to instability. In Afghanistan, British actions resulted in civilian casualties. This game is continuing. Despite ample evidence of war crimes, Britain has refused accountability, stalling efforts for reparations and justice. Meanwhile, with no substantive evidenceâ€”only fabricated claimsâ€”they continue to target Sri Lanka.  Sri Lankaâ€™s war was not one of conquest; it was a battle against a ruthless terrorist organization that turned children into suicide bombers. The LTTE (Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam) did not merely kill civiliansâ€”it enslaved its own community. Young Tamil girls were forcibly recruited, stripped of their childhoods, and sent to die in combat. Adele Balasingham, an Australian-born UK citizen, was one of the chief enablers of this human tragedy.  She lived in Sri Lanka, training these girls, tying cyanide capsules around their necks, preparing them for war. Today, she resides peacefully in the UK, a country which proscribed the LTTE, untouched by legal scrutiny. Why has she not been sanctioned? Why does the British legal system, so eager to hold select few Sri Lankans accountable, offer her protection instead of prosecution? The idea that the UK sanctions Sri Lankan individuals for human rights violations while allowing known terrorists and war criminals to live freely within its borders exposes the fraudulence of this entire exercise.  Why does Britain get to keep its plunder, while punishing others for their wars? How can the descendants of looters lecture the looted on ethics? This is not justice. Office going workers in Jam packed trains would travel with utmost fear not knowing which would be the next target for the terrorists.Â    Even the lives of school going children weren't spared, they were blasted to pieces in school entrances. Citizens at home were in fear whether their home would be the next target for looting by armed terrorists who were collecting funds for their movements. The Christian Europeans conquered us to produce non intoxicated brews like cocoa, coffee and tea. To produce rubber that was essential for mobility. Timber by clearing jungles in our countries for furniture. Conquered Africa for rain forest logging for construction . Alternative energy sources are everything from lithium batteries as the source, while fossil fuel is depleting.   It's very minimum that you can rely on wind, solar and other sources. Hydro power is very limited to some countries. If we start mining for minerals we will end up as the African continent, Burkina Faso, Niger or Nauru   Nauru inhabitants now have to move out of their country as there is no land for them to live on, they are left with just quarries after Mining for minerals. They led a very cozy life by Mining for minerals and being the wealthiest country on earth. They were relying on imported food supplies. Today they have no more minerals to mine and have no land to produce food and no money to import their food supplies.

In a well-functioning justice system, the burden of proof rests with the prosecution, meaning the defendant is presumed innocent until proven guilty beyond a reasonable doubt. Ideally, this standard of justification should also guide our public debates. However, in the realm of politics, emotions often take precedence, causing us to stray from this principle. I wish this debate had been more constructive, with both sides presenting evidence to support their claims and genuinely listening to each other. It is quite unfortunate that we couldn't see this in the interview.

This interview has sparked much commotion on Sri Lankan social media sphere, that was not only critical about Ranil Wickremasinghe but also the brand of journalism practiced by both the interviewee and the media organisation he works for.   I am yet to watch the full interview but a number of short clips that are long only one or two minutes that have been circulating on social media, I found to be unimpressive, and if at all, I thought, had, only a value in entertaining rather than in fact finding.  That said in my personal understanding the reasons and roots of Sri Lanka's recent economic crisis runs deep, they are nuanced, and complex, for which many scapegoats have been found except perhaps the real culprits.  It may one day warrants a deep scrutiny in a more academic manner rather than from journalists employed by media organisations, and their shows, whose successes are dependent on popularity and ratings for which various tacts and strategies are used to the extent, that the real essence of journalism is hard to find these days. Well blaming journalists alone would be disingenuous as most professionals and professions seem to have succumbed to a status quo that has jeopardized their integrity and character, which is a more troubling phenomenon than a crisis in a small island inhabted by few millions of people. In October 2018, a constitutional crisis unfolded when President Sirisena dismissed Wickremesinghe from his position as Prime Minister, appointing former President Mahinda Rajapaksa in his place. Wickremesinghe deemed this move unconstitutional and refused to vacate his office, leading to a political standoff. President Sirisena accused Wickremesinghe of corruption during this period, although no formal charges were filed. The crisis persisted until December 2018, when Rajapaksa resigned, and Wickremesinghe was reinstated as Prime Minister.

This man is behind most of Sri Lanka's Export Processing Zones, places like IET in Katunayake, NAITA, and pretty much the entire vocational training sector in Sri Lanka. He was instrumental in standardizing Sri Lanka's upper secondary education system, modeling it after the UK system (A-Levels and O-Levels). Every time he was in power, inflation rates were stable, and people had adequate food and essential supplies. He achieved all this without executive power, which he only held during his last two years in office. Remarkably, during that time, he managed to pull Sri Lanka out of bankruptcy with the same team from the Rajapaksa side. He had no other option but to work with the existing cabinet, from which shining stars like Kanchana and Ali Sabri emerged. He may have plenty of weaknesses, but compared to other options like Anura, Sajith, or Mahinda, he is undoubtedly the smartest leader of the bunch.

The credibility of international media has declined due to biased reporting, lack of independent verification, and agenda-driven narratives. Studies show that up to 80% of news in major outlets is not original, relying on press releases instead of investigative journalism.   Instances like Sky News Australia's misinformation on climate change and the BBCâ€™s biased coverage of the Israel-Hamas conflict have further damaged trust. As a result, public confidence in media has significantly dropped, with audiences gravitating towards sources that align with their beliefs. This growing distrust highlights the need for fact-checking and unbiased reporting to restore media credibility.

If youâ€™re here reading the comments, take a moment to read this as well.  I was born in Sri Lanka in 1994 and grew up in a culturally diverse environment shaped by Sinhala, Tamil, Portuguese, Dutch, English, French, and many other influences. I was educated in a system where I learned Sinhala, Tamil, and English. This exposure to different languages and beliefs taught me never to hate others based on their backgrounds. Instead, I choose to speak my mind when necessary and share my thoughts openly.  I am writing this because I question the true motives behind media outlets like Al Jazeera. Do they genuinely care about the Sri Lankan people? Do they love us? Do they truly want to support Sri Lanka? From what I see, their focus seems to be on targeting audiences who oppose certain political figures, stirring division, and potentially pushing the country back into the instability it endured a decade ago.  Growing up in Sri Lanka, I witnessed the impact of war firsthand. It took lives on both sidesâ€”Sinhala-speaking and Tamil-speaking alike. No war is fought with one hand clapping, and it is never a one-sided tragedy. As a citizen, I never wanted war, and I donâ€™t believe any ethnic group wished for it either. It was the result of political power struggles, not the will of ordinary people.  Yet, international media often frames the narrative to portray only one side as victims and the other as aggressors. They highlight allegations of war crimes by the Sri Lankan military while ignoring the reality that many Tamil civilians actively supported and funded the LTTE, fueling the conflict. I rarely see discussions about the Sinhala civilians who also suffered, who were displaced, attacked, and killed.  Now, in 2025, I look back and remember that what was lost were human livesâ€”not just Sinhala lives, not just Tamil lives, but human lives. And yet, some media outlets continue to sensationalize the past, reigniting divisions instead of helping people move forward.  Living in Canada now, I see how Sinhala-speaking people are often viewed differently due to narratives pushed by LTTE-supported media and politicians. I recognize that many Tamil people went through extreme brutality in Sri Lanka, as well as Sinhalese civilians. I acknowledge their suffering. But I also believe that distorting history and using selective narratives to demonize one side while glorifying the other does not serve justiceâ€”it only fuels further division.  I have many friends who are Buddhist, Muslim, Hindu, and atheist, and I was never raised to look at people based on their religious or ethnic identities. My values have always been driven by love and respect, not by the need to prove one belief superior to another.  Now, I see Al Jazeera bringing up the Easter bomb attack in Sri Lanka, clearly trying to manipulate emotions and take advantage of the pain it caused. I donâ€™t need foreign media to remind me of that tragedy, and I certainly donâ€™t need them using it to serve their own narratives. If they truly cared about Sri Lanka, they would approach these discussions with honesty, balance, and a genuine desire to helpâ€”rather than using selective storytelling to fuel agendas.  If they truly want to help Sri Lankan people, they need to look at the bigger picture rather than taking sides. War should not be about picking a winner and a loser; it should be about ending suffering. Whenever there is war, I believe it is important to look at the full picture rather than being blinded by emotions  and in the end, what is truly lost are the people we love.  I want to make it clear that I am not fighting for Sinhala people, Tamil people, or defending the Sri Lankan Army. What Iâ€™m speaking up about is how the media, particularly in this interview, tends to focus on only one side of the conflict. When the Sri Lankan Army is discussed in the context of brutality, it can easily be perceived as a broader attack on the majority Sinhala-speaking people. Thatâ€™s the nature of this type of coverageâ€”it often unintentionally extends the focus to the entire community, even when that was not the intent.  I understand that this interview addresses serious allegations against the Sri Lankan Army, but when the discussion is framed in this way, it risks oversimplifying a complex and painful history. This only fuels further division. The truth is that the war cost lives on both sidesâ€”Sinhala-speaking and Tamil-speaking alike. No war is fought with one hand clapping; itâ€™s never just one side that suffers. Itâ€™s a tragedy that affected all people, regardless of their ethnic background.  I fully acknowledge and respect the extreme brutality that many Tamil people faced during the conflict, and I honor their suffering. I recognize that the pain and loss they experienced is very real and significant. However, I also believe that distorting history and using selective narratives to demonize one side while glorifying the other only fuels further division. It does not serve justiceâ€”it hinders it.  Additionally, I believe that the Sri Lankan government must take the necessary steps to help locate those who have been lost during the conflict, regardless of their ethnic background. Both Tamil and Sinhala-speaking people have experienced the pain of missing loved ones, and it is critical that the government take action to address this issue and bring closure to families who still mourn their loss.  I am a Sinhala-speaking person because that is the language I grew up with. But donâ€™t marginalize me as just Sinhala, Sri Lankan, or anything else. There is more to me than those labels. At the core, I am a reflection of you. You are a reflection of me. If people truly want to find common ground, they must first explore themselves and recognize that, beyond all beliefs, we are humans. We are creatures of God, energy, or whatever force one chooses to believe in. We all belong to this planet, and that is our true home.

The journalist attempted to discredit Mr. Ranil, yet he did not succeed. It is evident that Mr. Mehdi possesses limited knowledge regarding the Sri Lankan Civil War and its historical context. The war did not begin with either Mr. Ranil or Mr. Rajapaksa. Rather, it was initiated by Velupillai Prabhakaran, who led the LTTE (Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam). It is important to recognize that Prabhakaran did not lead a pure struggle for Tamil Eelam, as some might claim. No evidence supports the assertion that the LTTE's leader was fighting solely to protect the rights of the Tamil people. On the contrary, Prabhakaran demonstrated a highly selfish approach to leadership. Prabhakaran remained safely ensconced in an underground concrete bunker with all the necessary comforts and amenities, while his community, the Tamil population, suffered during the war. When the Sri Lankan army advanced against the LTTE, the Tamil community, which was surrounded by LTTE forces, bore the brunt of the conflict. Following these attacks, the LTTE claimed that the Sri Lankan army had targeted innocent civilians, but these assertions were often seen as exaggerated or misleading. If Prabhakaran had been a true leader, he could have faced the battlefield, but he consistently remained sheltered in his bunker, communicating via satellite phone. If he were genuinely committed to his cause, it is reasonable to question why he never personally took part in the fighting. Furthermore, the widespread use of landmines in war zones, an unlawful practice under international law, and the numerous suicide attacks orchestrated by the LTTE, are further examples of the groupâ€™s disregard for the rules of warfare. Prabhakaran was responsible for many acts of violence, including the killing of Buddhist monks and attacks on mosques while people were praying. These acts raise serious questions about the legitimacy of his leadership and the claim that he was fighting for the creation of a Tamil Eelam. Meanwhile, Prabhakaran's own family remained safe outside of Sri Lanka, while the children in the Tamil-dominated North and East of the country were subjected to the harsh realities of war. The Sri Lankan government repeatedly attempted to broker ceasefires, but Prabhakaran rejected these offers, insisting on the demand for separate governance in the North and East. This raises further concerns about whether his motives were truly centered around the well-being of the Tamil people or whether they were driven by personal and political ambitions.

An Al Jazeera journalist asked Ranil Wickremesinghe whether he was the one who established the torture chamber known as Batalanda. During the interview, Ranil Wickremesinghe denied everything related to Batalanda. However, the journalist then questioned him again about Vincent Fernando from Trincomalee, who had given testimony before the Batalanda Commission. At that moment, Ranil became flustered and angrily responded.  Vincent Fernando, who was Ranil Wickremesinghe's lover, testified before the Batalanda Commission about his romantic relationship with Ranil and how he had been deceived. He also revealed the horrific acts of torture carried out under Ranilâ€™s orders within the Batalanda torture chamber. He made this statement in front of a panel of three judges. It was Chandrika Bandaranaike, a close friend and relative of Ranil, who ordered that his testimony be recorded in secret.  During the Al Jazeera interview, Ranil Wickremesinghe falsely claimed that Vincent Fernando never testified before the Commission. While it is true that Vincent did not testify publicly, he provided his statement privately. However, Ranilâ€™s political allies ensured that this testimony was not included in the official commission report.  Nevertheless, the true testimony of Vincent Fernando, whom Ranil Wickremesinghe denied, still remainsâ€”either with the Chairman of the Commission or with Chandrika Bandaranaike. Chandrika only used this information against Ranil during the 1999 election to intimidate him.  Two weeks after Vincent Fernando gave his testimony, Ranil Wickremesinghe was summoned before the Batalanda Commission. However, a week before Ranil's appearance, Vincent Fernando mysteriously died. Later, it was revealed that Vincent Fernando had been poisoned.  The crime was carried out by Sudath Chandrasekara, a police inspector and Ranil Wickremesinghe's chief security officer.  Detailed records of this incident are documented in the book "Setting Fire to Batalanda" by senior journalist Nandana Weeraratne.

For someone who segments this entire coversation based on points of discussion, it is evident that prominence was given to bringing up the wars crimes allegations against Sri Lanka reiterating that the then political and military leadership has created a genocide and atrocities against humanity. Whatever that was discussed about the Easter Sunday attacks, the 2022 Galle Face protests, the 83 riots, Batalanda commission as well as the recent economic crisis were only used to strategically steer the entire discussion towards the main motive. The composition of the panelists, the audience, and the questions they asked makes it clear.  Clearly, this interview was never meant to target or otherwise 'roast' RW. True, when one goes along his political timeline, all these incidents have a direct affiliation with him. Yet, the faces behind this interview wanted a prominent and eloquent Sri Lankan political figurehead to be on this platform to elaborate and reiterate on the allegations against Sri Lanka. This was purely a wake-up call for the international community, institutions, and interest parties and tell them 'now is the time'.  But most importantly, the underlying message this entire drama communicates is directed towards the current government, who will find it difficult to handle the international pressure on this aspect. Batalanda Commission report was brought from a retrospective point of view to trigger a deeper sentiment of the ruling party and its patrons. Eventually, they will be forced to align with the desires of the above. A country without a direction, a state without the rule of command, a vulnerable economy, and a collapse of institutions will drive the nation towards an unforeseen abyss with a loss of sovereignty.

He may not speak as fast as the journalist, but that does not mean his responses should be cut off before they are fully articulated. While each person has their own opinions and facts, I wanted the opportunity to understand his perspective and learn something new.  Not all of us research extensively, and this could have been a moment to hear his rationale on key issuesâ€”whether one agrees with him or not. Instead, much of the discussion was dominated by accusations and interruptions, making it difficult to follow his stance. For example, when he tried to explain his role in stabilizing the economy and the difficult decisions required, he was constantly interrupted with hostile counterpoints before he could even finish a thought.  Similarly, on topics like human rights and the Rajapaksa family, there was no room for a balanced discussion. When he pointed out that legal actions are decided by the Attorney General, not the President, the focus immediately shifted to personal optics, like his attendance at a birthday party, instead of addressing the actual judicial process.  I am not on anyoneâ€™s side hereâ€”I just wanted an opportunity to learn more. But all I could gather was a barrage of allegations and an arrogant, combative approach that left little space for real dialogue. Give the man time to answer the questionsâ€”whether itâ€™s the answer you like or not.

This video raises important points, but it's crucial to acknowledge the full complexity of the Sri Lankan Civil War. As others have stated, it's equally important to recognize the LTTE's documented history of violence against civilians of all ethnicities. They employed tactics like suicide bombings and child soldiers, causing immense suffering. Balanced reporting is essential for understanding this tragic conflict. We cannot ignore the suffering of all Sri Lankan citizens. For more information, I would recommend researching reports from the UN, and also looking into reports from Human Rights Watch.  Furthermore, it's essential to address the ongoing concerns regarding asylum claims by some Sri Lankan Tamils in other countries. There have been allegations, sometimes substantiated, that some individuals exaggerate or fabricate accounts of persecution by the Sri Lankan military to strengthen their asylum applications. This practice, while not representative of all asylum seekers, can contribute to a skewed perception of the conflict. Reports from various immigration tribunals and government assessments in countries like Canada, the UK, and Australia have documented instances where asylum claims based on alleged military persecution were found to be unsubstantiated or inconsistent. It is important to remember that this does not diminish the very real suffering of many, but it is a factor that must be considered when looking at the overall narrative. True peace can only be achieved through acknowledging the pain of all the victims, and by having a full and honest understanding of the conflict.

In a serious interview format like â€œHead to Headâ€ the focus should be on the guest, not the interviewer. The interviewers job is to challenge, probe and clarify, but not to overshadow the person being questioned.  Constantly interrupting instead of letting the guest answer is a bad behavior in an interview like this.  I think Ranil Wikramasinghe answered all the Qs very well. The interviewers opinions made the answers look a bit odd. It was a psychological trick he was playing by commenting after each answer and going into the next question or showing a gesture like the answers donâ€™t make sense. That is called â€œovershadowingâ€ the interview, which is a defect of the interviewer. Here, the interviewer try to become the star without letting the guest to speak.  I also think RW would have taken different approaches to answer some of the Qs. But in my opinion. RW played well.

Ranil Wickremesinghe became the President of Sri Lanka after the Aragalaya (GotaGoGama) protest led to the resignation of Gotabaya Rajapaksa. Despite not being elected by the people, he was appointed by Parliament with the support of the Rajapaksa-led SLPP, which allowed him to take power.  While initially portraying himself as someone who would restore stability, Ranil played a key role in dismantling the Aragalaya movement. Under his leadership, the government used force to clear protest sites, arrested activists, and introduced stricter measures to suppress dissent. Many view him as the main strategist behind the crackdown, ensuring the survival of the political establishment that the people protested against.

Batalanda Torture Chambers, the Fertilizer Factory, Ranil Wickremesinghe, and Vincent Fernandoâ€¦  ğŸ”´ Sapugaskanda Fertilizer Factory In 1975, the United Front government established the State Fertilizer Corporation and began constructing an industrial plant on approximately 100 acres of land in Sapugaskanda to produce urea. Alongside this, a housing complex with 64 fully equipped houses was built in the nearby Batalanda area for the officials involved in the project.  By 1979, when the construction of the plant was completed, the UNP government was in power. The plant had a production capacity of 980 metric tons per day. However, with the introduction of an open economy and the importation of fertilizers, the value of this factory declined. Eventually, the houses in the housing complex were leased out to external organizations.  ğŸ”´ Ranil Wickremesingheâ€™s Arrival at Batalanda Batalanda falls within the Biyagama electorate, where Ranil Wickremesinghe was the MP. At that time, he served as the Minister of Youth Affairs and Employment. He began using one of the luxury houses in the housing complex as a ministerial guest house.  Later, in February 1989, he was appointed Minister of Industries, under which both the fertilizer factory and the housing complex fell. He then designated House A/2/2 as his official residence and assigned House A/2/3 to his caretaker, Vincent Perera.  According to the Batalanda Commission Report, several houses in the complex were allocated to senior police officers who were unofficially working with the Peliyagoda and Kelaniya police, without the knowledge of either the Inspector General of Police or the Ministry of Defense. Among them were Kelaniya Assistant Superintendent of Police Douglas Peiris and Ranil Wickremesingheâ€™s personal security officer, Sudath Chandrasekara. It is unnecessary to elaborate on why these houses were provided to the police.  The then-Inspector General of Police, Ernest Perera, testified before the Batalanda Commission, stating that he had no knowledge of houses B8, B10, B13, B20, B21, and B34 being allocated to the police. Additionally, two more houses were used as Ranil Wickremesingheâ€™s offices.  ğŸ´â€â˜  Batalanda Torture Chambers The torture chambers were operated in these houses with the knowledge of then-President Ranasinghe Premadasa and Minister of Defense Ranjan Wijeratne. The commission revealed that six houses were used as torture chambers, four of which were confirmed. Two of these houses were directly used by Ranil Wickremesinghe, while the other two (B8 and B34) were allocated to the police.  It is believed that during the peak period of repression in 1989â€“1990, around 4,000 young men and women were tortured and killed at this location.  ğŸ‘¨â€â¤ï¸â€ğŸ‘¨ Ranilâ€™s Alleged Lover, Vincent Fernando Al Jazeera journalists inquired about Vincent Fernando, who was the caretaker of the bungalow and reportedly Ranil Wickremesingheâ€™s close associate. Due to fear, he testified before the Batalanda Commission in secrecy, stating that Ranil Wickremesinghe had knowledge of the events occurring in the torture chambers.  However, Chandrika Bandaranaike allegedly decided not to include his testimony in the commission report, possibly due to political ties. Vincent Fernando, who testified believing in Chandrikaâ€™s government, mysteriously died a few days later due to poisoning. Al Jazeera, I sincerely applaud your team for this remarkable interview. This is what true journalism looks like, asking the right questions to the right people without fear or bias.  Watching this interview left me with mixed emotions, satisfaction that these critical questions were finally being asked, but also deep shame at the way former President Ranil Wickremesinghe responded. His dismissive, unprofessional, and almost childish behavior only proved how unfit he was as a leader. He thought he could evade responsibility with empty rhetoric, but the truth remains: under his leadership and those before him, Sri Lanka was brought to its knees.  No accountability for war crimes. No justice for the victims of the Easter attacks. No remorse for the economic collapse that devastated millions. Our country was bled dry by corrupt leaders who prioritized personal gain over the well-being of our people. For years, we lived in fear: freedom of speech was a death sentence, dissent meant disappearing without a trace. And as this interview highlighted, there was clear conflict of interest among former presidents, proving how deeply the system was rigged against the people. A leader must separate personal ties from professional duty, but they never did.  I also want to express my deep regret for the disgraceful comment made by Ranil Wickremesinghe about Mahatma Gandhi. It was a pathetic attempt to dodge accountability, and it further exposed his lack of integrity. No leader should exploit the name of a revered figure to escape answering for their failures.  Justice must prevail. Collective responsibility must be enforced. We are finally seeing a glimmer of hope with the new government, and the truth will come out. Al Jazeera, I urge you to continue this work! Bring in the Rajapaksas, Sajith Premadasa, and all those responsible. If they have nothing to hide, they should have no reason to fear the truth.  Sri Lanka deserves justice. The people will not forget. The people will not forgive.  â€”A Sri Lankan Citizen: Perera

While his involvement in suppressing the JVP insurrection in the late 1980s remains unclear to me, I view him as progressive, accommodating, and measured in his approach. Tamil militancy emerged as a response to the gradual encroachment on Tamil lands and rights by successive Sinhalese governments. However, the LTTE was far from innocentâ€”they were violent, deeply distrustful of political processes, and oppressive in their own right. The pervasive culture of hatred, violence, and impunity must end. Time offers the best hope for change, and I remain optimistic about a future generation of leaders who can avoid these pitfalls. I hope young people will engage in the political process and dismantle the outdated framework of race-based politics. Greater days lie ahead for this beautiful island, but only if the lessons of the past are truly heeded.

A real journalist should uphold professionalism, fairness, and respect in interviews. While pressing for answers and challenging statements is part of good journalism, constantly interrupting the interviewee can come across as unprofessional and biased. Ideally, a journalist should allow the speaker to respond fully before asking follow-ups, ensuring a balanced and meaningful discussion. If the journalist in question repeatedly disrupted the conversation, it raises concerns about their approach and adherence to journalistic standards. This is what I daw with this so called real journalist!  If a journalist consistently interrupts and only allows partial answers to steer the conversation toward their own narrative, it compromises journalistic integrity. A real journalist should aim to uncover the truth, not manipulate responses to fit a predetermined agenda. This approach can distort public perception and misrepresent the speakerâ€™s actual views. Ethical journalism requires allowing the interviewee to fully express their thoughts, even when being challenged. If a journalist selectively controls the conversation to validate their own viewpoint, it leans more toward advocacy or bias rather than objective reporting.

Why don't you focus on the civil war...As the journalist says, the whole world has heard that the Sri Lankan army killed innocent people...Why doesn't anyone talk about the innocent people killed by the Tamil Tigers, including their community? Were only Tamils â€‹â€‹killed? How many ordinary people were killed by the LTTE? Even though the war was in the north, the LTTE planted bombs all over the country and killed people...They massacred small children, pregnant women, and villagers...But what the army did was to give even the people who escaped the LTTE a chance to eat. Why doesn't anyone talk about that truth here...Sixteen years after the war ended, as a country and a nation, we have not been able to tell the world a true story about the war...They still only accept what the LTTE-friendly journalists said. They don't talk about the suffering that the country as a whole suffered,  They make documentaries about the miserable conditions in the LTTE camps and talk about the war... There are still people suffering because of the war all over the country... They only talk about the missing LTTE members. They are terrorists... They took up arms to kill unarmed civilians and small children to win over their leader. If they say they sought peace through that, it is a big joke... There is no point in talking about Ranil... Because we have always known whether the things they say about their politics are true or not... But we must stop giving the world a wrong idea about the war... If this continues like this, in about ten years, other communities in this country will be the culprits and our future generations will say that the LTTE was right. I watched the entire program... The Sri Lankan army is only accused of war crimes internationally. During the war, we saw the army as God... Those people risked their lives to protect Sri Lanka... All four nations can live freely... Even today  I always respect those great people for that.  The entire program shows the LTTE as innocent... that the army and others killed them for nothing... No one mentions the massacres that the LTTE committed by killing all the inhabitants of the villages, even small children.

Watched this interview with complete disgust. This was not an interviewâ€”it was a blatant display of disrespect toward the former Sri Lankan President. Instead of conducting a fair and balanced discussion, the panel seemed intent on attacking and undermining him.  The presence of PEARL, an organization based in the USA known for its efforts to discredit Sri Lanka, further exposed the biased nature of this so-called interview. It was evident that the discussion was not meant to facilitate meaningful dialogue but rather to corner and pressure the President.  A major concern is the complete absence of any Sinhalese representation. How can such an interview claim to be fair and objective when there is no effort to include diverse perspectives? Instead, the President was subjected to a hostile interrogation, with multiple participants talking over him, dismissing his responses, and refusing to engage in a respectful conversation.  While it is understandable that tough questions need to be asked in any high-profile interview, this was not responsible journalismâ€”it was an ambush. The sheer imbalance, combined with the presence of individuals aligned with anti-Sri Lankan narratives, raises serious questions about the motives behind this interview. Where was the UK High Commission while the Sri Lankan President was essentially placed in a firing line, forced to reveal national matters under intense pressure?  If Al Jazeera claims to uphold journalistic integrity, then we challenge them to conduct an interview with Donald Trump or any other Western leader in the same aggressive and disrespectful manner. Would they dare speak to them like this? Or is this biased treatment reserved for certain nations and leaders? Why was no mention of the terrorist activities of the LTTE Tigers?  This was an utterly disgraceful interview, devoid of professionalism, fairness, or genuine journalistic ethics.

ğŸŸ¥ The Al Jazeera journalist asks if you created the Batalanda torture chamber. In that discussion, Ranil Wickremesinghe denies everything about Batalanda, but the journalist again asks about the Trincomalee youth Vincent Fernando who testified at the Batalanda Commission! Then Ranil gets upset and answers angrily!  Ranil Wickremesinghe's boyfriend Vincent Fernando has revealed before three judges his love affair with Ranil Wickremesinghe at the Batalanda Commission, how he capriciously deceived him, and the horrific torture carried out at the Batalanda torture chamber on Ranil's orders. This statement was ordered to be taken secretly before the three judges by Ranil's friend and relative Chandrika Bandaranaike. Ranil Wickremesinghe tells Al Jazeera that Vincent Fernando did not appear before the commission and gave evidence. It is true. Vincent Fernando gave evidence in private. His classmates had also taken steps to prevent it from being included in the commission report. However, the actual statement of his lover, Vincent Fernando, which Ranil Wickremesinghe rejected, is still with the chairman of the commission, either with the judges or with Chandrika. Chandrika used it only to intimidate Ranil during the 1999 election against Ranil.  Two weeks after Vincent Fernando gave his statement, Ranil Wickremesinghe was summoned before the Batalanda Commission. Vincent Fernando had died secretly a week before Ranil was summoned before the Batalanda Commission. It was later revealed that Vincent Fernando had been poisoned to death. The crime had been committed using Police Inspector Sudath Chandrasekara, Ranil Wickremesinghe's main bodyguard. A detailed account of this is recorded in the book "Batalandata Ginilema" by veteran journalist Nandana Weeraratne Soyura.  - Copied.

Ranil Wickremesinghe, as the former President of Sri Lanka, showed exceptional leadership during the countryâ€™s most challenging moments in 2022. Amid a severe economic crisis, widespread protests, and political instability, he stepped into a situation where many others hesitated. Despite facing immense criticism and difficult circumstances, Ranil demonstrated resilience and commitment to stabilizing the country.  His decision to take on the presidency during such a turbulent period was not one made lightly, but rather with a sense of responsibility to restore order. He took bold steps to negotiate with international creditors, implement financial reforms, and try to bring about economic stability. He worked tirelessly to secure assistance from global institutions, aiming to protect Sri Lanka from further economic collapse. Ranilâ€™s pragmatic approach to diplomacy and crisis management helped steer the country through a time of uncertainty.  While no leader is perfect, itâ€™s important to recognize the efforts of those who step up during the darkest times, especially when they attempt to address deep-rooted challenges. Sri Lankans should appreciate the hard work and dedication that Ranil Wickremesinghe put into lifting the country, even when it seemed like all hope was lost. As a Sri Lankan, I had a hellish feeling about our country until September 21, 2024, that everything was taken over by an extremely corrupt ruling clique that was enjoying itself by deceiving and oppressing the people by all the lawless state institutions and politics controlled by the corrupt. But patriotic people have been struggling in various ways to save this country from this corrupt politics for many years. Among them, JVP founder Rohana Wijeweera cannot be forgotten. It is not surprising that in our country, since then, they have betrayed their country, nation, money and power in front of things like that. But today, it has been confirmed before our eyes that the corrupt journey that the majority of the people have taken so far has brought the country to anarchy. As my grandfather and father said, the reason why there are LTTE terrorists in our country is because of JR. Jayewardene becoming the president of the country and the racist and religious concepts he adopted. But when I study this, I think differently. I see the LTTE as a conspiracy to ensure the long-term existence of this political elite and the corrupt political clique. The reason for this is that at times the political elite of that time even provided weapons to this LTTE. There is ample evidence for this. I see the founder of JVP, Rohana Wijeweera, as someone who saw all these conspiracies from afar. He and his patriotic colleagues were destroyed by the then President Ranasinghe Premadasa and Ranil Wickremesinghe, including the state police and the army, during the 88,89 terror period. But they could not destroy its essence. Today, what Rohana Wijeweera said has become a true reality. For these reasons, the people were able to form a government of the National People's Power led by Anura Kumara Dissanayake, which was led by another patriotic organization of people led by the JVP built by Rohana Wijeweera. Ranil Wickremesinghe is addressed in Sri Lanka as the "tormentor of the Batalanda". I proudly declare that the people are no longer stupid enough to bring Ranil Wickremesinghe and the Rajapaksa gang, who resorted to theft, corruption and state-sponsored murder to maintain their power, to power again in Sri Lanka. Mahinda Rajapaksa is the leader who took the initiative to end the war in the country. But since that time, he and his gang have been exploiting the people of the country, creating small leaders who deceive the people on the surface and give them a share of this state money and work only thinking about maintaining power. It is a well-known secret that Rajapaksa planned the Easter attacks during the 2015-2020 regime. But as a result of the bad work he did, the country's economy collapsed and the public uprising was so powerful that Gotabaya was forced to hide. The Rajapaksas stepped down from the scene, using the power of parliament again and handing over the task of protecting the Rajapaksas to Ranil Wickremesinghe. So you can understand that all these people are like one. Whether Ranil is from one political party or Rajapaksa is from another party, they are all one. At the moment of trouble, they are one. Who stood for the people? They are the current rulers of the country. If there is anything to be gained from this, look at the problems in the countries of all those who see this, and take only the good. No matter what, all people are equal. In death, you have to go alone. Let this be an example for all those who appoint good rulers for their country.

The primary reason for the breakdown of harmony between the Sinhalese and Tamil people in Sri Lanka is neighboring India. The Tamil people living in the state of Tamil Nadu have historically desired a separate country for themselves. Have they ever wanted to identify themselves as Indians? They have always identified themselves as being from Tamil Nadu. To prevent Tamil Nadu from becoming a separate state, India cunningly attempted to convince them that Sri Lanka was their rightful homeland. This led to the emergence of the LTTE organization, which killed thousands of innocent civilians from both nationalities. Interview Style Comparison Al Jazeera Direct and Confrontational: Al Jazeera often adopts a direct approach with rapid-fire questioning. This style is designed to expose inconsistencies and hold public figures accountable. The questions are usually backed by thorough research and legal or factual evidence.  Intense Pressure: The format pushes interviewees into a high-pressure situation where evasion is difficult. This can lead to visible emotional responses if the interviewee feels cornered or unfairly targeted.  BBC Hard Talk Rigorous and Inquisitive: BBC Hard Talk similarly employs a methodical approach, emphasizing well-prepared questions that are often rooted in detailed evidence and historical context. The aim is to extract clear, accountable answers on complex issues.  Balanced Yet Persistent: While also direct, Hard Talk tends to maintain a balanced tone, combining firmness with a degree of respect. The interviewer usually allows space for detailed responses but remains persistent in seeking clarity on controversial points.  Comparative Impact: Both platforms use rigorous questioning techniques. However, BBC Hard Talk often strikes a slightly more measured tone, balancing confrontation with an effort to maintain a constructive dialogue, whereas Al Jazeera's approach can be more overtly aggressive, potentially leading to more immediate emotional reactions.  Behavior of the Former President Emotional Response and Public Perception: When a former president responds to challenging questions with anger and insults, it signals discomfort and defensiveness. This reaction may suggest that the individual is either unprepared to address the rigorous evidence presented or feels personally attacked by the questioning style.  Professionalism Under Scrutiny: Both interview styles are designed to test a leaderâ€™s accountability. An inability to respond calmly under such scrutiny can harm the leader's credibility. The reactionâ€”whether in the form of emotional outbursts or verbal insultsâ€”might be interpreted as a sign of underlying issues, such as unresolved controversies or a gap between past actions and current responsibilities.  Contextual Considerations: The broader political and historical context, such as contentious events from a leaderâ€™s past, can further fuel such intense responses. The behavior observed in interviews may reflect deeper internal conflicts or pressures that extend beyond the immediate conversation.  Conclusion Both Al Jazeera and BBC Hard Talk are known for their rigorous, evidence-based interviewing techniques, though their approaches differ slightly. Al Jazeera's method is often more confrontational, potentially provoking stronger emotional reactions, while BBC Hard Talk tends to balance firmness with a respectful tone, aiming for detailed accountability without escalating tension excessively. In cases where a former president becomes visibly upset and resorts to insults, it raises questions about their readiness to confront challenging issues and maintain professionalism in the face of intense scrutiny.

Mehdi equating the action taken against mobs planning to attack Parliamentâ€”an act influenced by current government members, as openly acknowledged by Mr. Lal Kanthaâ€”to the arrest of Gotabaya over his allegations is misleading. These are two entirely different matters. The former falls under emergency powers exercised by the President in response to immediate threats to national security, whereas the arrest of Gotabaya would require a civil legal process through the judiciary, not a direct action by the President. There is no evidence that Mr. Ranil Wickremesinghe interfered with the judiciary to shield Gotabaya; instead, he upheld judicial independence, which is fundamental in a democracy. A President does not have the authority to arrest individuals directly. What Mr. Ranil said here is correct.

First and foremost, this discussion extended well beyond two hours, as confirmed by former Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe in a press conference. The way the discussion was edited appears to undermine his role and significance.  To begin with, the program presenter lacked the patience and professionalism required to conduct a balanced discussion. The audience mainly consisted of individuals with affiliations to the LTTE, a known terrorist organization, which continues to have active networks in the UK and Europe. While there may be no direct evidence of LTTE funding for this program, anyone watching can clearly see that the entire discussion was well-scripted and strategically executed. The individuals who posed questions and provided explanations appeared uninformed about the true history of the conflict, seemingly acting according to a pre-arranged script.  The Sri Lankan ethnic war was financially and strategically influenced by external entities, including India, the UK, and European nations. Various forms of international sanctions against Sri Lanka further strengthened the opposition. Historically, India played a role in training and arming the LTTE, which eventually led to the assassination of Indian Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi. In the final stages of the war, thousands of lives were lost as both sides fought for survivalâ€”Sri Lanka in defense of its sovereignty and the LTTE for its own agenda.  The journalist conducting the discussion appeared to follow a pre-planned script, but the execution was poorly organized. The questions lacked logical flow, and the presenter consistently interrupted Ranil Wickremesinghe, preventing him from providing detailed responses. This suggests a deliberate effort by the organizers to limit his ability to articulate his thoughts effectively.  Furthermore, a woman named Rasarathnam, who was involved in the discussion, had connections with the LTTE and even served as an advisor to the group.  Overall, this discussion was deeply flawed due to conflicts of interest at multiple levels.  For further insights into the origins and operations of the LTTE, I recommend reading "Tigers of Lanka" by Narayan Swamy.

Batalanda mass murder ---  An Al Jazeera journalist asked whether it was you who established the torture chamber called Batalanda. During that interview, when Ranil Wickremesinghe completely denied everything related to Batalanda, the journalist questioned him again about a young man named Trincomalee Vincent Fernando, who had testified before the Batalanda Commission. At that moment, Ranil became agitated and responded angrily.  Winston Fernando, who was allegedly Ranil Wickremesinghe's lover, testified before the Batalanda Commission about his romantic relationship with Ranil, how he was deceived, and the horrific acts of torture that were carried out under Ranil's orders at Batalanda. This testimony was given in front of a panel of three judges. It was Chandrika Bandaranaike, a friend and relative of Ranil, who ordered that this statement be taken confidentially.  Ranil Wickremesinghe told Al Jazeera that Vincent Fernando never testified before the commission, which is true. Winston Fernando gave his testimony privately, and his statements were omitted from the commissionâ€™s report by his old classmates. However, the true testimony of Winston Fernando, which Ranil rejected, still remains either with the chairman of the commission or with Chandrika. Chandrika only used it to intimidate Ranil during the 1999 elections.  Two weeks after giving his statement, Winston Fernando was summoned before the Batalanda Commission, which had also called Ranil Wickremesinghe. However, a week before Ranil was to appear, Winston Fernando mysteriously died. Later, it was revealed that he was poisoned. The crime was committed by Sudath Chandrasekara, a police inspector who was Ranil Wickremesingheâ€™s chief security officer.  Detailed information about this incident is recorded in the book "Batalanda to Ginileema" by senior journalist Nandana Weeraratne.    ---

*The Damdeepa Policy: A Historical Engine for the Structural Genocide of Tamils in Sri Lanka*  Sri Lanka's political and cultural landscape has been significantly influenced by the ancient text, the Mahavamsa, which has served as a cornerstone for shaping the country's identity. For centuries, this chronicle, which narrates the story of the Sinhalese people and their divine right to rule the island, has played an instrumental role in crafting the Sinhala-majority narrative. However, for Eelam Tamils, this text is not merely a history book; it is a powerful ideological tool that has been used to justify their marginalization and oppression. Central to this process is the Damdeepa policy, a political framework that advocates for a Sinhalese-dominated Sri Lanka, and in turn, has paved the way for the systematic suppression and genocidal actions against Tamils.  Mahavamsa: A Tool for Political Exclusion  The Mahavamsa, an ancient chronicle written in the 6th century, traces the history of Sri Lanka from its mythical founding by Prince Vijaya to the rule of King Dutugemunu, who is venerated as a national hero for his conquest of the Tamil Chola kingdom. The narrative, deeply rooted in Buddhist ideology, frames the Sinhalese as the rightful rulers of the island, with a divine duty to protect Buddhism. In the Mahavamsa, Tamils are often portrayed as enemies or foreign invaders, and this portrayal has played a critical role in constructing a Sinhalese-only identity that has left little room for Tamil aspirations.  For Sinhalese nationalists, the Mahavamsa has been employed as a political justification for the dominance of the Sinhalese majority over other ethnic groups, particularly the Tamils. It has cemented the belief that the Sinhalese people hold a divine right to the island, creating an ideological framework that frames Tamil struggles for autonomy, self-determination, and equality as rebellious and illegitimate. This deeply ingrained political philosophy, embedded in Sri Lankan history and politics, has caused the marginalization of Tamils, especially those in the northern and eastern provinces.  The Damdeepa Policy: Fueling Tamil Marginalization and Erasure  The Damdeepa policy, or the "Island of Light" policy, is a direct extension of the ideologies rooted in the Mahavamsa. This policy embodies the vision of a Sinhala-dominated Sri Lanka, where the Sinhalese identity is prioritized and Tamil identity is subordinated. It envisions Sri Lanka as an exclusively Sinhalese state, with Tamils viewed as a minority whose rights to autonomy, political power, and cultural recognition must be suppressed.  The Damdeepa policy has been used to politically exclude Tamils, economically marginalize them, and deny their linguistic and cultural rights. In its most brutal form, this policy justified the violence and discrimination faced by Tamils, both during the civil war and in its aftermath. From the beginning of Sri Lanka's post-colonial history, Tamils have been forced to navigate a system of governance that disregards their rights, driven by an ideology that asserts Sinhalese supremacy and seeks to erase the presence of Tamils from the islandâ€™s political and cultural narrative.  Eelam Tamils: Victims of a Historical Injustice  For Eelam Tamils, the influence of the Mahavamsa and the Damdeepa policy is not a relic of the past but a living, breathing force that continues to shape their daily existence. The historical narrative presented in the Mahavamsa has entrenched the idea of a Sinhalese-only Sri Lanka, leaving no room for the legitimate aspirations of the Tamil population. The political philosophy derived from this text has systematically excluded Tamils from the political process and undermined their quest for self-determination.  The Tamil struggle for a separate state of Tamil Eelam emerged as a direct response to this exclusion. The Tamil Eelam movement sought to create a state where Tamils could live in peace, free from the oppression and marginalization that had defined their existence under Sinhala rule. For many, the inability of the Sri Lankan government to address the grievances of the Tamil population, compounded by the ideological and political forces stemming from the Mahavamsa, amounts to a form of genocide. The displacement, violence, and denial of justice faced by Tamils are viewed as part of a larger ongoing process of erasureâ€”a deliberate attempt to remove Tamils from the political and cultural fabric of Sri Lanka.  The Tamil Struggle: Challenging a Genocidal Narrative  Tamils view the denial of justice for the victims of the Sri Lankan civil warâ€”particularly the atrocities committed in its final stagesâ€”as a continuation of a pattern of historical denial that stretches back to the very formation of the Sri Lankan state. The refusal of the Sri Lankan government to allow independent investigations into the war crimes committed by its forces, along with its failure to provide justice for Tamil victims, is seen as an extension of the systemic oppression of Tamils, rooted in the political philosophy of the Mahavamsa and the Damdeepa policy.  For Tamils, seeking justice is not only about addressing the atrocities of the war but also about challenging the ideological and political structures that have allowed such violence to persist. The fight for recognition, autonomy, and self-determination remains central to the Tamil cause, and the denial of justice is viewed as an ongoing act of historical erasureâ€”a denial of the very existence and dignity of the Tamil people.  Conclusion: A Call for Justice and Recognition  The political philosophy that emerged from the Mahavamsa and was enshrined in the Damdeepa policy continues to have a devastating impact on the Tamil population of Sri Lanka. For Eelam Tamils, these ideologies have served as the foundation for systematic exclusion, discrimination, and the denial of their political, cultural, and social rights. The fight for justice, recognition, and self-determination cannot be separated from the historical context in which the Sinhalese-only state was createdâ€”one where Tamil identity was consistently undermined and erased.  Without meaningful recognition of Tamil rights, culture, and history, the cycle of marginalization and victimization will persist. The Tamil struggle for justice is a struggle against the continuation of a historical injusticeâ€”a struggle for the right to exist as a people with the dignity and recognition they are entitled to.  In the face of continued denial, it is essential for the international community to stand with the Tamils of Sri Lanka in their quest for justice, ensuring that the cycle of oppression and genocide does not continue for generations to come. The lack of accountability in Sri Lanka's political system has allowed corruption and mismanagement to persist, leading to severe economic and social consequences. Successive governments have failed to take action against those responsible for the bond scam and the Easter Sunday attacks, reinforcing the perception that political elites protect one another. The appointment of the Attorney General by the President, as outlined in the 54th Constitution, raises concerns about the independence of the legal system and its ability to prosecute those in power.  Despite initially supporting the Aragalaya movement, Ranil Wickremesinghe swiftly suppressed protests upon assuming office, highlighting a pattern where political leaders exploit public sentiment for their own gain. This cycle of governance has placed an immense burden on taxpayers while allowing politicians to evade responsibility. Without structural reforms, greater transparency, and independent institutions, Sri Lanka risks remaining trapped in a system where justice is denied, and public trust continues to erode.

Ranil is such a fool
what is the difference between a civil war and terrorism 0:45?  Scale and Participants:  Civil War: Involves organized groups or factions within the same nation fighting against each other. Typically, the conflict is large-scale, prolonged, and involves conventional military forces. Terrorism: Usually involves smaller, non-state groups or individuals using targeted violence against civilians or symbolic targets to create fear or influence political decisions. Objectives:  Civil War: Generally aims to seize political control, achieve independence, or drastically change the political structure of a nation. Terrorism: Primarily aims to instill fear, influence public opinion, destabilize governments, or achieve political or ideological objectives indirectly through psychological pressure. Tactics:  Civil War: Employs conventional warfare tactics, including organized battles, territorial control, and sustained military engagements. Terrorism: Relies on unconventional tactics such as bombings, kidnappings, assassinations, and sabotage, deliberately targeting civilians or symbolic locations to maximize psychological impact. In short, a civil war is characterized by organized internal conflict with clearly defined factions and military confrontations, whereas terrorism is marked by strategic violence designed to generate fear, usually involving smaller groups and civilian targets.

Sri Lankan here, some more facts from the ground and from someone who was at Temple Trees when Gotabaya resigned:  - Sri Lanka's protests were amongst the most peaceful in the world, the image Ranil is painting that parliament and the capital were in complete chaos after Gota's removal is COMPLETELY FALSE. Ranil himself said he would "step down" if Gotabaya attacked protestors. The army were sent to dismantle the main protest site that was miles away from parliament  - Ranil DID NOT appoint Nandalal (his party actually attacked Nandalal) nor did he start talks with the IMF. Both are things he's tried taking credit for  - India gave us $2 billion before Ranil came in to power and as a resulted solved the fuel crisis. This is something Ranil repeatedly pretends never happened to prop up his "saviour" image  - Multiple crisises happened during Ranil's tenure including an unchecked hunger and medical one. This was repeatedly kept on the down low to help with Ranil's image despite the problems reaching insane levels to the point where a corrupt MP from the previous govt imported fake medicine  - The economy "stabilizing" is quite literally due to the govt turning off most of the economy and waiting it out, the immense pain the public felt during this process is not to be trivialized as if it was a gentle process, it was a culling that depended on foreign aid and a huge amount of support from NGOs and charities like Save The Children  - The suicide rate stopped being recorded during his tenure  - Cabraal (the governor of the central bank who suggested printing more money) was removed by Gotabaya and not Ranil. By Ranil's logic should we praise Gota for that or is this just common sense?   - Ranil's election history does not mirror Thatcher's at all, Thatcher won 3 elections in a row and made huge changes to the country before rightfully being kicked out after her 3rd term   - 15:22 is very much true and a crucial point, the common excuse from Ranil apologists is that he's "powerless" but the fact is there were cases that indeed could have easily been re-opened   - Ranil prevented any reforms and aided members from the previous govt, he held no credible inquiries in to the Rajapaksas and did nothing about corruption, none of the Rajapaksas faced any punishment or were prosecuted in any common sense faculty (evidence of crimes is overwhelming). Yes, our attorney general is corrupt, this is a fact that Ranil pretends isn't true and again, its obvious when blatant crimes have been committed by both him and his Rajapaksa friends (Ranil sending the army to GGG for e.g. is a blatant violation of the constitutions and was publicly televised, the proof is overwhelming). If justice takes this long despite overwhelming evidence then he has failed regardless of his intentions  - Ranil's entry in to politics is directly a result of nepotism and not merit and his uncle was the president who started a 30 year long race war  Ranil is a psychopathic liar who preys on pseudo-intellectuals and is the face of pretentious politics. His legacy of 50 years of politics will be that of a loser, one can only imagine he even accepted this interview in the first place as a desperate attempt to win back validation from actual smart people otherwise there would be no reason for him to do this

It was evident throughout this discussion that the anger in the West to end the war has not yet subsided.  interview  mostly deals with the thirty-year war and the events that took place in its final stages to obtain the question paper.  Mehdi Hassan tried hard to get Ranil to admit that war crimes were committed in Sri Lanka, and that war heroes like Shavendra Silva who were on the front lines and the commanders Mahinda Rajapaksa and Gotabaya were the ones who committed them.  Ranil saved them all in front of the international community, and it is his personal opinion that the international community has no right to come out and say that the thirty-year war has ended.  If Ranil had been a traitor to the English Tamil diaspora and international organizations, this questionnaire could have been milder.  Hassan quotes someone who is not as knowledgeable about international politics as Ambamal Renuwaka as attending Mahinda Rajapaksaâ€™s birthday as a big deal.  Throughout the discussion, there was a need for revenge against war heroes for ending the war by the pro-LTTE Tamil diaspora.  Despite the hostility he has faced in his personal political life since 2005 and despite his usurpation of the prime ministership in 2018, Ranil Wickremesinghe has shown the role of a true patriot by not betraying war heroes including Mahinda Rajapaksa, Gotabaya, Shavendra and others in front of the international community.  The international community, which is talking about the deaths in the last week of Mullivaikkal, has not said a word about the hundreds of thousands of people killed by the Tigers in the South over the past 30 years.  Domestic problems should be at home, and outsiders should not be allowed to have domestic problems.  This government will also have to face a similar situation in the future. At that time, this government must choose whether to betray the war heroes and get Western favors, or stand up for the war heroes and the political leaders who led during the war.  Despite the many mistakes of the Rajapaksas, because of the leadership he gave to end the thirty-year war, everyone as a country should stand with him to support all the patients coming from the international community and the diaspora.  (Not about the frauds and corruption that occurred after the war)  Finally, my sorrow for the runaway jeppa who is running away with Ranil Wickremesinghe. Ruvin Fernando

A truly strong interview would balance tough questioning with deep analysis, allowing viewers to gain a clearer picture of both past failures and future possibilities. Some interviews focus on assigning blame rather than deeply analyzing the root causes of Sri Lanka's crises A good journalist should allow to answer the question without interrupting. Many Head to Head interviews rely on aggressive questioning. While this can be effective, excessive interruptions or confrontational tones might not allow the guest to fully explain their stance.

Ranil W took tough decisions that stabilized the country.  He could not do anything to the Rajapaksas because he could only rule successfully with parliament support.   He ensured a free and fair presidential election was held.  All of this made it easier for the current government to do what they are doing today.  Having said that, he came to power under a Rajapaksa majority parliament. He lied that he got elected because of the SJB and Tamil parties. These parties only had about 68 seats in a parliament of 225. Ranil got 134 votes.  About the EPF, he lied. Even though no money was taken from the provident fund, the changes made ensured that the member of this fund would lose around 47% of what the fund would have generated for them in the next 16 years. People are losing money on this even today.  He dissolved all committees/commissions when he came to power and shelved all investigations carried out a few months before he became president. This would have led to investigations into Rajapaksa regime financial corruption. Instead, Ranil appointed new committees that were filled with Rajapaksa stooges. The COPE committee became a joke. It seems like many of the commentators haven't actually watched Mehedi's interviews with people. In these interviews, he rarely lets the person he's speaking with finish their answer. Instead, he often interrupts, cutting them off before they can fully explain themselves. This results in him positioning himself as the one who is always right, leaving the interviewee seemingly unable to defend their point of view. He then takes credit for the conversation, making it look as though he has all the answers.  Before commenting negatively about Ranil, I would suggest that these commentators take the time to watch Mehedi's interviews. This way, they can better understand his interviewing style and the way he controls the conversation. It might provide them with a more balanced perspective and allow for a more informed discussion.

Iâ€™d like to point out that this interview seems rather one-sided. In my view, the LTTE was a terrorist organization, one of the most brutal in modern history, and was responsible for serious war crimes. Regardless of political affiliation, anyone who commits a crime should face punishment. While some argue that the trauma of war and events like Black July in 1983 (an incident that the LTTE initiated, before that there were tensions building) might explain certain actions, I believe that those who profess genuine care for the Tamil community yet idealize the LTTE are promoting a deeply biased, racially charged perspective. Finally,  I want to emphasize that the conflict is over and communities are coming together. It's important not to be swayed by those who exploit divisive rhetoric for political or personal gain.

Ranil Wickremesinghe took charge of Sri Lanka at one of the darkest moments in the nationâ€™s history. With the country facing an unprecedented economic collapse, severe shortages of essential goods, and civil unrest, his leadership was pivotal in stabilizing the situation and preventing a humanitarian catastrophe.  Upon assuming office, President Wickremesinghe swiftly implemented economic reforms, secured international financial assistance, and took decisive action to restore essential supplies of food, medicine, and fuel. His diplomatic efforts were instrumental in negotiating with the International Monetary Fund (IMF), restoring investor confidence, and rebuilding Sri Lankaâ€™s credibility on the global stage.  Despite immense political and social challenges, he remained steadfast in ensuring that Sri Lanka did not descend into deeper chaos. His leadership helped the nation regain stability, ease the suffering of millions, and set the foundation for long-term economic recovery.  We, as a nation, owe a deep sense of gratitude to President Ranil Wickremesinghe for his unwavering commitment to protecting Sri Lanka during its most perilous times. His resilience, wisdom, and strategic vision have safeguarded the country from collapse, paving the way for a hopeful future. Thank you, President Wickremesinghe, for standing firm in the face of adversity and defending Sri Lanka when it needed you the most.
